SAYS: I think it would be very useful if there was a way that we could walk new people through how to use the website.
Most people who are successful right away either go to the orientation and walk through it there or they meet somebody like Debbie Rare and have a personal view orientation step by step.

If there was some type of video or app or even a committee of people who would be willing to walk people through the website, the people that are sort of non-very computer literate would have a better experience up front.
I also think that the navigation can be improved because people have a hard time finding where they want to go.
I think they want to see what are my tickets, where am I going, and what can I sign up for right now?
I think it would be also good if the navigation was segmented by category, especially the 20 to 40s and the 40 and above so that people could find what they're looking for easier.
I think that it would be really important to include the day of the week of the events like Thursday or Friday because that's not always clear.
If you sign up for the waiting list, it's not clear how many people are on the waiting list.
This should be possible to list on the website.
It might be good to have that be also available in the summary.
THINKS: Users who are not computer literate are at a disadvantage when using the website.
There is a need for a more guided approach to help new users understand the website's functionalities.
Improving navigation could significantly enhance user experience and accessibility.
Users may feel overwhelmed or confused by the current layout and lack of clear information.
There is a belief that transparency in event details (like waitlist status and costs) could lead to better user satisfaction.
DOES: The user likely seeks out orientations or assistance from more experienced individuals to navigate the website.
They may rely on personal connections to get the information they need about the website.
They might engage with the website but experience frustration when they can't find what they're looking for.
The user may check for events but may not follow through if the necessary information (like cost) is not readily available.
FEELS: Frustration with the current navigation and lack of clarity on the website.
Concern for users who may struggle with technology and how that affects their experience.
Aspirations for a more user-friendly website that accommodates all levels of computer literacy.
Anxiety about missing out on events due to unclear information or complicated navigation.
Joy at the prospect of a more organized and accessible website that would enhance user experience.
